ratings.comment: I loved Aaron's class. A lot of people don't understand how pedantic film creation and analysis can be, but Aaron taught well while making sure it wasn't lethally boring.

I loved Aaron. I always looked forward to his lectures and found him to be inspiring. His passion for filmmaking really comes through in his lectures. This class made me look at film in a completely new way.

Aaron is a great professor in my opinion and it sucks to see so many bad reviews about him :( It's a hard course geared towards com arts majors, so if this is something where (like me) you are trying to gain knowledge in a field that you love, you'll enjoy this course. However, I will agree video projects are scattered and kind of busywork.

I don't know if Aaron is technically a professor but that is beside the point. This class is pretty difficult, but that's more because of your TA than Aaron. Sure, some of the things he says are a little strange, but I found myself enjoying his lectures as much as any others.

Aaron is a passionate instructor who really cares about the material, education, and his students. The projects are a fair bit of work, but I really enjoyed taking 355. If you have the option, take this class during the summer, but if you take it during the school year, definitely go into office hours and really get to know him and your TA!
This really could be an online lecture with labs. I aced the final but wouldve received a higher if attendance wasnt a factor.

He seems like a nice guy but he does not know how to run a course. There are too many overlapping projects, that are graded far too harshly for a course at this level. The lectures start incredibly early while discussions are much later in the day, and 2 hours long, and needlessly so. Do yourself a favor and never take this course, it's infuriating

This class was actually so awful. I would not recommend this class to my absolute worst enemy. Class is three credits and has quadruple the amount of work that my four and five-credit classes had. Lecture and lab was pointless and we were required to be there for both. My TA (Megan) was terrible and not very knowledgeable. 1/2

Aaron is a good lecturer and genuinely wants his students to succeed. That being said, CA355 has been one of worst classes I've taken at UW Madison. The work load is insane for a 3-credit class, my TA was awful (and annoying tbh) and everything was graded really harshly. Aaron is a great guy but I wouldn't recommend this class to anyone.

1st project:short video of techniques w/partner 2nd project:film recreation of a movie scene w/partner 3rd project:own film-individual project projects were easy to do but they require effort and time outside of class. cast your own actors, learn how to edit film. All projects overlap, so you will have to be on top of projects and due dates.

Aaron's grade is FAR too low on here. He is such a laid-back and caring guy. As mentioned below, lectures are mandatory and can get very dry but he truly does his best to be interesting which is appreciated. Like everyone has said, it's a work-intensive class and labs are too long. However, in the end, it's still the most beneficial class I've had.

I actually enjoyed waking up and going to this class. Aaron is hilarious and does his best to keep class entertaining. I wish he could have utilized class time a bit better, and use better quiz questions. This being said, the class is much more work than most other classes that I have taken. Be prepared to work hard outside of class.

Aaron is great. His lectures are sometimes boring but you'll like them if you're really into movie production. His quizzes are from books and lectures and are sometimes very detailed, so beware of that. But you can always get extra credits. The final project is big so take it seriously

I'm not sure why so many people have had an issue with Aaron/this class. He was a hilarious professor who does his best to make lecture interesting despite the dry, technical material. If you're into film and take this class seriously, you will learn a lot. Grading on projects is tough and labs are probably a little too long, but a great class.

This may seem hyperbolic, Aaron is one of the worst professors I have ever had.  attendance is mandatory (including pointless lectures and excessively long 2-hour labs). He thoroughly eradicated any of the fun parts of production. Also, the quizzes are terribly made. An actual question i received was "Who spoke first  in this scene from Se7en"

I was dreading taking this class and I'm so glad it's over. It is sooo much work and they give you barely any time to finish projects. You also have to make your own short film but they do not have enough camera equipment for everyone which is a serious problem. Lectures were too early and I felt like it was all common sense. Wouldn't recommend.

Aaron's a funny guy. Tries to make class fun & interesting, but like others have said this class has so much potential. Lectures are boring, but the hands on parts are fun if you're in to film/editing! This takes a lot of out of class time, and is a lot of work for one/two people to manage. Definitely take CA155 before if interested in this class!

This class had such potential. Aaron seems like a cool person but manages to take an interesting, fun topic and making it boring and tedious. Lectures feel like pulling teeth, you will plead internally for it to be over every time. Do not take this class unless you have to.

Don't take this class unless it's required for your major. Even though it's an intro class, the grading was pretty harsh - questions on the midterm were super specific and some of them seemed completely irrelevant ("define these random, obscure terms from the textbook"). Lectures are pointless, esp. if you took 350, yet they are mandatory.

If he weren't hot, he'd be the worst professor ever. His lectures are so boring, and he's just stretching the material to last for 50 minutes. And on top of that, attendance is mandatory. He tries his best to make the lectures more entertaining because he is really funny, but it's not enough to save the class. Projects are fun but lectures TANK.

Aaron is a super funny guy however, as a professor, his lectures are extremely boring, at it doesn't help that they are at 8:50 am. They take attendance at lectures but you can miss 3. The projects require lots of time out of class, and the deadlines come up fast. Labs are kind of boring too. This class had the potential to be really fun.

I liked the lectures, and they were fun. The only problem is that the class is an Introduction to Media Production and it feels like we are being graded as if we should already know how to use a camera or editing. We were graded very harshly and expected to do perfectly, which is hard when you have never done any production before.
Terribly unclear grading criteria, but at least the class is interesting

CA 355 lectures suck because they're early, and the material is dull with a lot of repeat from CA 350. That being said, Aaron does his best to make lecture fun, and he is really funny. The class itself has been one of my favorite experiences because it gives you the chance to be creative in a cool way
He broke his jaw and couldn't speak.  Very funny professor.

lecture is mandatory but you're allowed to miss 3. Aaron likes to joke even if it's early so take it or leave it. I really enjoyed his lectures because they introduced the material that we would be going over in lab. Felt very prepared for his tests but I still got a C, be very specific in your answers. Overall, very fun! I enjoyed the production.
His bad attitude left me dreading his lectures.

Aaron teaches extremely basic skills used in the production of cinema, making the content seem like common sense. He is EXTREMELY uninteresting to listen to, lecture is VERY boring/useless. He makes the class dull, monotonous, and stupid. Don't take it with him, you'll hate the class. Tests are mild. Hard to achieve an A. Avg grade received is a B.

Aaron's job is making movies and doing awesome things with the camera so he knows what he's talking about. Go to every lecture otherwise because he doesn't write much on the slides. Study Guides for the Midterm and Final - they're lengthy but use them he can be a hard grader. The Doc and Narrative projects are stressful but they grade easy on those
